questions.question: Which system call in 1979 laid the groundwork for process isolation?
questions.explanation: The chroot (change root) system call allowed a process to change its root directory, creating a limited view of the file system.

questions.question: What is the primary architectural difference between a Virtual Machine (VM) and a Container?

options.text: VMs share the host kernel, Containers do not
Containers include a full Guest OS, VMs do not
Containers share the host OS kernel, VMs include a full Guest OS

questions.explanation: Containers share the underlying host operating system's kernel, while VMs run a complete instance of a guest operating system on top of a hypervisor.

questions.question: Which Linux kernel feature provides resource limiting (CPU, RAM)?
questions.explanation: Control Groups (cgroups) are a Linux kernel feature that limits, accounts for, and isolates the resource usage (CPU, memory, disk I/O, network, etc.) of a collection of processes.

questions.question: What happens if you try to 'chroot' into an empty folder without a shell binary?

options.text: It works and automatically provides a shell
It fails because the folder has no binaries to execute
It creates a new virtual machine

questions.explanation: A chroot jail is just a restricted view of a directory. If that directory doesn't contain a shell (like /bin/bash or /bin/sh) and its dependencies, you cannot execute anything inside it.
